parameter 1: The cut scenes include one with a Cameo by Stephen Chow (Xing-Chi Chiau) as a cop with his police dog.
parameter 2: In Russia the movie is called "Volt", because "Bolt" is Russian slang for penis.
parameter 3: SPOILER: - The missing sequence is placed just before the final shot of the film. After the shot of child monk in the rowboat, in the cut scenes the child monk is shown putting stones into the mouths of a fish, a frog, and a snake; these scenes emphasize the film's themes of the circularity of life. The film then continues to its final scene of the Buddha statue on the hill.
parameter 4: The cut scenes include one with a Cameo by Stephen Chow (Xing-Chi Chiau) as a cop with his police dog.
parameter 5: The original UK cinema release of Bone (and its video release) lost 3 minutes, and was missing the end of the scene where Bill (Andrew Duggan) presents a car advertisement (we don't see Bill looking into the cars and seeing that they are filled with dead bodies) and the end section of Bill's conversation with a woman in a bar. It seems these cuts were made by the distributor.
parameter 6: SPOILER: - The missing sequence is placed just before the final shot of the film. After the shot of child monk in the rowboat, in the cut scenes the child monk is shown putting stones into the mouths of a fish, a frog, and a snake; these scenes emphasize the film's themes of the circularity of life. The film then continues to its final scene of the Buddha statue on the hill.
parameter 7: The English version, The Tin Flute, was shot simultaneously with the French version, as well as two five-hour TV series.
parameter 8: A 112 minute theatrical version in 35mm widescreen, blow up from 16 mm, was authorised by the director.
parameter 9: In the German version, the hamster's name has been changed from Rhino to Dino.
parameter 10: Because the dialogue is half English, half French, both versions shared the same soundtrack. The only difference is in the subtitles: in the French version, English dialogue was subtitled, and in the English version, it was the French dialogue.
parameter 11: The cut scenes include one with a Cameo by Stephen Chow (Xing-Chi Chiau) as a cop with his police dog.
parameter 12: In the French version, Bolt is called Volt and dubbed by 'Richard Anconina' (qv)). The two actor cats and the various pigeons are voiced by comedic duo 'Omar Sy' (qv) and 'Fred Testot' (qv). All French cinemas carrying the 3D version of the film showed it exclusively in its French dub. The film in its original English (with French subtitles) was only shown in 2D. A goof occurs when re-lettering the written name. The dog's tag and the billboards seen, read Volt during the first part of the movie, but read Bolt later on.
parameter 13: The original UK cinema release of Bone (and its video release) lost 3 minutes, and was missing the end of the scene where Bill (Andrew Duggan) presents a car advertisement (we don't see Bill looking into the cars and seeing that they are filled with dead bodies) and the end section of Bill's conversation with a woman in a bar. It seems these cuts were made by the distributor.
parameter 14: The English version, The Tin Flute, was shot simultaneously with the French version, as well as two five-hour TV series.
parameter 15: Because the dialogue is half English, half French, both versions shared the same soundtrack. The only difference is in the subtitles: in the French version, English dialogue was subtitled, and in the English version, it was the French dialogue.
parameter 16: In the German version, the hamster's name has been changed from Rhino to Dino.
parameter 17: Because the dialogue is half English, half French, both versions shared the same soundtrack. The only difference is in the subtitles: in the French version, English dialogue was subtitled, and in the English version, it was the French dialogue.
parameter 18: US version soundtrack includes Moussorgsky's A Night on Bald on Mountain.
parameter 19: Available on VHS/DVD in both R and unrated versions. (Unrated version runs 3 min. longer.)
parameter 20: A 112 minute theatrical version in 35mm widescreen, blow up from 16 mm, was authorised by the director.
parameter 21: An updated version was created in 2006 to include interviews with cast members from _Casino Royale (2006)_ (qv). It is this version which was released to DVD in 2007 as a special feature with Casino Royale.
parameter 22: A 112 minute theatrical version in 35mm widescreen, blow up from 16 mm, was authorised by the director.

It seems these cuts were made by the distributor.
parameter 24: US version is cut by 22 minutes.

parameter 27: US version is cut by 22 minutes.
parameter 28: The English version, The Tin Flute, was shot simultaneously with the French version, as well as two five-hour TV series.
parameter 29: The local Korean version of this film is approximately 90 seconds longer than the International release; a sequence was removed near the end of the film (at about the 100-minute point). This is reflected in the DVD releases, as the Tartan R2 (UK) release and the Columbia/Tristar R1 (USA) release use the International cut of the film, while the Bitwin R3 (Korean) DVD uses the original cut.
parameter 30: In the French version, Bolt is called Volt and dubbed by 'Richard Anconina' (qv)). The two actor cats and the various pigeons are voiced by comedic duo 'Omar Sy' (qv) and 'Fred Testot' (qv). All French cinemas carrying the 3D version of the film showed it exclusively in its French dub. The film in its original English (with French subtitles) was only shown in 2D. A goof occurs when re-lettering the written name. The dog's tag and the billboards seen, read Volt during the first part of the movie, but read Bolt later on.

parameter 34: The English version, The Tin Flute, was shot simultaneously with the French version, as well as two five-hour TV series.
parameter 35: When this movie aired on Cartoon Network in the 1990s, the popular songs Snoopy listened to in the pub were replaced with generic instrumental tunes, most likely due to music rights.
parameter 36: The cut scenes include one with a Cameo by Stephen Chow (Xing-Chi Chiau) as a cop with his police dog.
parameter 37: The 18-rated UK release of this film was cut by 18 seconds by the BBFC.
parameter 38: In the German version, the hamster's name has been changed from Rhino to Dino.
parameter 39: Due to demand, Unearthed Films has released this on DVD in an unrated form, restoring 10 minutes of gore (as said on the commentary) as well as a few new scenes to further enhance the story.

parameter 50: The German version has sounds of the ending credits to about 1:48, then the opening credits sounds replace the ending credits sounds. Some prints of the german version also have the video of De Angelis brothers singing Fantasy, the movie's theme almost after the ending credits.
